ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Enhanced my multi-variable calculus skills
Multivariable calculus and some applications in physics
How to tackle various problems involving multiple variables.
This was a very solid way to learn multivariable calculus, without having to focus on the tedium that I have heard math 120 involves.

- basic fundamentals of multivariable calculus 
- special focus on applications to physics and engineering
I learned important reasoning skills and key multivariable calculus principles.

You learn to think critically about multivariable calculus and how to apply it to different scenarios. The last chapter of the semester (flux, Stoke's, Green's, etc) is very valuable as a foundation for engineering.

I learned how to access resources, such as Peer Tutors, to help me learn difficult material. I also learned a lot about how STEM courses at Yale/in college function so that I could better adapt to my next one. I also learned the benefit from asking upperclassmen for their help in a course, because often they provide feedback on how the course works and how to be more efficient with it.
multivariable calculus
I was introduced to multivariable calculus. I think this course taught me how to study in a college environment.
Multivariable calculus

I learned A LOT about multivariable calculus. The instructor wasn't necessarily the best at explaining the topics, so a lot of personal effort outside the classroom goes into actually understanding what's happening. After you get over the learning curve, it's all butter.
multivariable calc with some physics applications
Doing calculus functions with multiple variables. Understanding 3D and greater graphs.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good class
Good teaching quality. Lectures were highly organized and included great examples to help students parse difficult concepts.
The flipped classroom is not effective in my opinion
The prerecorded lectures are really helpful for understanding the material and allow for actual class time to be used on questions and example problems.

This class, while still a higher level math class, was very reasonable on the workload and offered a lot of resources and support (recorded lectures from last year, lots of practice, office hours) to help learn the material.

Strength 
- flipped classroom so there is lots of time for questions 
- lots of material to practice with 
- exam are very fair 
Weaknesses 
- sometimes class problems can jump from easy to hard out of nowhere
One weakness is the flipped classroom style it is currently taught in. I'd prefer to learn in class.
Lots of access to helpful resources like peer tutors, office hours, and review problems.

Strength: Professor Ozolins is an amazing instructor and person. The exams were relatively fair (although the first exam is rather difficult). PSets were pivotal to learning concepts properly and deeply (make sure to go to office hours as psets can be quite challenging and cover material beyond the pre-recorded lectures); similarly, TAs made this course much more bearable. Personally, I got by by just watching the pre-recorded lectures (did not open the textbook) and UNDERSTANDING how to complete the pset problems and in-class problems. Although there is no curve, the class distribution seems to work out pretty nicely at the end of the semester; the overall grading structure is quite forgiving if you put in the effort to improve.
Weakness: This was the first class I've ever taken where we watch a pre-recorded lecture and then do difficult problems in class (I think the pre-class quizzes could be a little longer with increasing difficulty as you go on and an explanation on how to actually do each problemwould make class time more valuable). It was quite discouraging to attend class as it seemed like I was the only one that did not understand how to do some of the problems (but rest assured, most people are also confused at first... practice, practice, practice!) The pre-recorded lectures could be shortened or at least cut out irrelevant material and replace it with more reinforcement style teaching.

The strengths of this course include its peer tutor, Tiffany Liao, and the amount of material covered throughout the semester. The weaknesses include the little engagement during lecture as well as the professor's teaching style. I believe the course could be improved if the prelectures as well as class lectures were more engaging.
It's good

I did not love the reverse classroom set up. At times it was difficult for me to learn the material on my own. I wish there was a bit more lecture in class although practice problems are important too.
Interesting material with a great professor, really helpful TAs. Lectures could be really dry at times and were sometimes the exact same as the recorded lectures plus a few more examples

Multivariable calculus? Yes. For engineers? Not so much. This class assumes students already have a conceptual understanding of how multivariable calculus works. There really weren't any applications and the grading curve works against you. There are so many overachievers in this class that makes it really hard to get a good grade even with a decent average.
taught very well, psets were pretty manageable, exams were pretty reasonable
I think it's good that they test understanding how to do problems rather than giving us super extreme arithmetic.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
Yes, as an alternative to MATH 120.
I wouldn't recommend this as a "for fun" class unless you're good at math.
Only if needed for your major, but definitely better than MATH 120.
Yes, if you have to take multi or want to take higher math at Yale for whatever reason, this is a very reasonable course and is not too painful.
Yes, really good class for engineers. Also the workload is very reasonable and the Professor and TA's make themselves available.
Yes, necessary for engineering and a good math course to challenge yourself.

Yes. This course was taught very well by Professor Ozolins, and we were learning content at a quick but manageable pace. Through solving a variety of problems in class and on p-sets, we were able to master the concepts very well.

Only if necessary, this is not a class to take "for fun." It is quite challenging and moves VERY quickly. That being said, I think I would recommend it over Math 120 simply because the amazing TAs and supportive Professor Ozolins. ENAS 151 definitely has more challenging midterms and psets BUT the cheat sheet allowed balances out the difficulty in that respect; as well, Professor Ozolins WANTS you to succeedjust reach out to him. This course is definitely more self-guided and expects discipline of its students, make sure to practice practice practice before exams. The grading structure is also much more fair than Math 120.

I would recommend this course if the student had to take multivariable calculus during their time at Yale. However, I think that the workload is absurdly high and would warn that the problem sets are extremely time-consuming. This course is difficult.
YES MATH 120 IS FOR THE BIRDS ENAS FOR LIFE
Yes, I did enjoy it overall. If a student was interested in taking a multivariable calculus class I would definitely recommend this course.
Yes, take this over MATH 120. Vidvuds is fantastic.

Try shopping Math 120. I think the curve for that class is much better. At the end of the day, if you have to take Multi, it probably doesn't matter which course you take. If you don't have any experience, you better work hard from the start to get the conceptual stuff down before things start going fast.
Yes, it's taught much better than what I've heard about math 120.  It was very helpful to take alongside phys 180.
Yes, you learn about the applied maths of Multivariable Calculus which is useful and required for most engineers.
